message_1: A pair of twins, Alex and Bob, are born on Earth. Alex stays on Earth while Bob travels in a spaceship traveling at a speed of 0.8c (80% of the speed of light) for 5 years and then returns to Earth. According to the Twin Paradox, how much time will have passed for Alex and for Bob when they are reunited on Earth?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we need to use the concept of time dilation in special relativity. Time dilation occurs when an object is moving at a significant fraction of the speed of light relative to an observer. In this case, Bob is moving at 0.8c relative to Alex, who is stationary on Earth.

The time dilation formula is given by:

t' = t / sqrt(1 - v^2/c^2)

where t' is the dilated time experienced by the moving observer (Bob), t is the time experienced by the stationary observer (Alex), v is the relative velocity (0.8c), and c is the speed of light.

First, we need to find the time experienced by Bob during his journey. Since he travels for 5 years away from Earth and then 5 years back, the total time experienced by Alex is 10 years.

Now, we can find the time experienced by Bob using the time dilation formula:

t' = 10 / sqrt(1 - (0.8c)^2/c^2)
t' = 10 / sqrt(1 - 0.64)
t' = 10 / sqrt(0.36)
t' ≈ 10 / 0.6
t' ≈ 16.67 years

So, when Bob returns to Earth, Alex will have experienced 10 years, while Bob will have experienced approximately 16.67 years due to time dilation.
